title: Moss Glen Falls: Vermont's Most Beautiful Waterfall Hike
author: SummitSeeker Team
excerpt: A stunning 125-foot cascade just steps from the road—Moss Glen Falls in Stowe is one of Vermont's most beautiful and accessible waterfalls.

seo.meta_description: Moss Glen Falls hiking guide for Stowe, Vermont. Visit this stunning 125-foot waterfall on an easy trail perfect for families and photographers.

content.introduction:
Vermont has two waterfalls named Moss Glen Falls—one in Granville and one in Stowe. Both are beautiful, but the Stowe version is particularly impressive: a 125-foot cascade dropping over a stepped rock face, framed by lush moss and ferns. It's just a short walk from the parking area, making it accessible to almost everyone.

The falls are especially dramatic in spring when snowmelt swells the stream, but they're worth visiting any time the trails are clear. Photographers particularly love the soft light of overcast days, when the falls seem to glow against the green moss.

sections.heading: The Trail
sections.content:
Basic Stats

  • Distance: 0.5 miles round trip
  • Elevation Gain: 150 feet
  • Difficulty: Easy
  • Time: 20-30 minutes

The trail begins at a small parking area and follows a well-worn path through the forest to the falls. The final approach involves some rock steps and can be slippery when wet—use caution, especially with children.

A viewing platform provides the classic view of the falls, but adventurous visitors can scramble closer (carefully) for different perspectives.

sections.heading: The Falls
sections.content:
Moss Glen Falls drops approximately 125 feet in a series of steps over ancient rock. The cascade is surrounded by:

  • Lush moss: The namesake—thick green moss covers the rocks
  • Ferns: Creating a prehistoric forest atmosphere
  • Hemlocks: Tall trees frame the scene

The falls split and rejoin over their descent, creating patterns in the water that change with the flow. In spring, the full power of the cascade is impressive; in summer, the delicate threads of water are equally beautiful in a different way.

sections.heading: When to Visit
sections.content:
• Spring (April-May): Peak water flow; trail can be muddy
  • Summer: Lower flow but beautiful lighting through forest canopy
  • Fall: Colorful foliage frames the falls
  • Winter: Ice formations can be stunning; trail may be icy

Photography Tips

  • Overcast days provide even lighting and saturate the greens
  • Use a tripod and slow shutter for silky water effect
  • Bring a lens cloth—spray reaches the viewing area
  • Early morning offers solitude for unobstructed shots

sections.heading: Practical Information
sections.content:
Getting There

The trailhead is on Moss Glen Falls Road in Stowe, about 3 miles from the village center. Take the Mountain Road (Route 108) toward Smugglers Notch, then turn right onto Randolph Road, followed by Moss Glen Falls Road.

Parking

A small parking area accommodates 8-10 cars. On busy days, additional roadside parking is available.

Fees

No fee to visit. The falls are on a combination of public and conserved private land.

Accessibility

The trail is not wheelchair accessible due to rough terrain and rock steps near the falls. However, the short distance makes it manageable for most visitors.

Combining with Other Activities

Moss Glen Falls pairs well with other Stowe attractions:

  • Stowe Pinnacle (nearby summit hike)
  • Stowe Recreation Path (paved walking/biking)
  • Village of Stowe (shops, restaurants)
  • Smugglers Notch (dramatic mountain pass)

sections.heading: The Other Moss Glen Falls
sections.content: Vermont's other Moss Glen Falls, in Granville Gulf, is also worth visiting if you're touring the area. That waterfall drops directly beside Route 100—you can view it from your car or a short roadside path. Both falls share the mossy, lush character that makes Vermont waterfalls distinctive.

Moss Glen Falls is Vermont at its most enchanting—a dramatic cascade wrapped in moss and mist, accessible to almost anyone willing to take a short walk. It's the kind of place that makes you understand why people fall in love with this state. Don't miss it when you're in Stowe.
